head.title: Sniffing Around New Cars for the Sweet Smell That Sells

hedline.hl1: Sniffing Around New Cars for the Sweet Smell That Sells

abstract.p: Automobile manufacturers go to great lengths to create signature odors for new cars, since aroma can be deal breaker among some new buyers; amalgam of odors can draw buyers to new car or can turn them off; drawing (Special section, Cars) (M)

block.p: FOR many car buyers, the aroma of a new car can be a deal breaker. New car smell -- an amalgam of odors from the rubber, leather, cloth, plastic and chemicals used in making the car -- can draw buyers to a car the way an animal is drawn to its kin. Or it can turn them off. If the smell reminds them of a wicked aunt's old Buick or gives them the sense that they are losing brain cells from the chemicals, they may change their buying decision.

FOR many car buyers, the aroma of a new car can be a deal breaker. New car smell -- an amalgam of odors from the rubber, leather, cloth, plastic and chemicals used in making the car -- can draw buyers to a car the way an animal is drawn to its kin. Or it can turn them off. If the smell reminds them of a wicked aunt's old Buick or gives them the sense that they are losing brain cells from the chemicals, they may change their buying decision.

Which is why manufacturers go to great lengths to cultivate a signature smell. They treat the leather and the upholstery and sometimes add aromas, with luck that the bouquet may spark that sensor in the buyer's nose and send a message to his brain that says, ''Buy.''

Their work is apparent, as I discovered when I sniffed my way around the 100th New York International Auto Show recently at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. It took two trips: the air in the center is quite dry, and a warm, moist atmosphere is best for smelling. Still, the aromas were unmistakable. Every car I sniffed had its own bouquet. Some were seductive, some reminiscent of familiar aromas, some just plain awful.
TOYOTA ECHO -- Gold exterior, gray upholstery. A direct hit of fruity perfume underlined by wet dog.
CHEVROLET MALIBU LS SEDAN -- Navy blue with neutral tan upholstery. A cross between a sour pickle and a tennis-ball can.
CADILLAC DE VILLE -- Pearl gray with gray leather interior. Warm and welcoming, well-balanced fragrance of flowers, berries, leather and wood: much like an old library.

CADILLAC ELDORADO -- Cherry red with white leather seats. Like the DeVille, this car has a strange warmth emanating from the white leather, though it smells disconcertingly like a Gruyere cheese omelet.
BMW 528i -- Ice blue with dark-camel leather interior. A decadent bouquet of earthy leather, face cream and ripe peaches.
LAND ROVER DISCOVERY -- Dark green with taupe dimpled-leather interior. A hint of leather but mostly heady doses of overripe bananas.
MERCEDES E320 AWD STATION WAGON -- Teal blue with mist-gray leather interior. The aroma is not warm and fuzzy but has a pleasant bouquet of wet rock and seawater.
GMC SIERRA -- Black with gray leather interior. Smells like the first-class section on an old 747; bubble-gum sweet with a vague aroma of food, worn leather and plastic.
ROLLS-ROYCE SILVER SPUR -- White and sand colored with sand and camel leather seats. This car smells so intensely of earth, animal and wood you can practically taste it.

ROLLS-ROYCE SILVER SERAPH -- Silver with gray leather. The all-leather interior is intoxicating; a combination of seawater, mint and tar. It makes you wonder if your clothes will smell after you get out of the car.
VOLKSWAGEN NEW BEETLE -- Silver with inexpensive-looking gray leather seats. Warm and floral, possibly contributed by a wilting daisy in the built-in vase.
FORD FOCUS -- Blue with gray upholstery. The first inhale is nothing other than Play-Doh, densely aromatic Play-Doh. A clear sour odor follows.
MITSUBISHI SSS CONCEPT CAR -- Silver with gray leather interior. The future smells of dry, aged wood, spices and chemicals.
QVALE MANGUSTA -- Yellow with black leather interior. A spicy, musky aroma that leaps out as you open the door.
ASTON MARTIN DB7 VANTAGE -- Sea green with sea green and cream leather interior. It smells at once of an indoor tennis club and a warehouse full of rawhide.
SAAB 9-3 -- Fire-engine red with tan leather seats. A heady collision of wax, sweet leather and tropical fruit.
Amanda Hesser is a reporter in the Dining section of The Times.
